Eligible companies must be registered in France (not necessarily as their headquarters) and meet one of the following conditions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eYoung Innovative Enterprise (JEI) status (a package of tax credits and social-contribution exemptions for R\u0026amp;D-heavy start-ups)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003especific state funding for innovation within the past five years\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFrench VC backing\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003emembership in a partner accelerator or incubator\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"French tech visa"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Deep Blue"},"value":{"value":"deep-blue"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Scrolling"},"value":{"value":"scrolling"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Deep Blue"},"value":{"value":"deep-blue"}}},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"4"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eTo help female entrepreneurs overcome disadvantages in gaining finance and support, Australia\u0026rsquo;s government started a Boosting Female Founders Initiative program, which offers grants from AU $25,000 to AU $480,000. The program provides not only targeted support for scaling in domestic and global markets but also expert mentoring and advice. For this program, Australia\u0026rsquo;s government has announced a total of AU $52.2 million in grant funding, over multiple rounds.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"An Australian initiative for female founders"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Scrolling"},"value":{"value":"scrolling"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Gray"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"5"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eIsrael is a small country with just over nine million inhabitants but has a GDP of near $500 billion, more than 2.5 times that of Hungary. Its economic success is fueled by both its start-up ecosystem and the strength of its strategic industries\u0026mdash;biotech, cybersecurity, pharma, specialized engineering, and technology. To help start-ups, the Israeli Innovation Authority runs a variety of research grant programs, ranging from general all-access grants to grants for companies founded by minorities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe authority also provides specific research grants for start-ups in sectors strategically important to the Israeli national economy:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe Ideation Incentive Program provides grants of up to $30,000 in the initial development stages. It is generally open to start-ups in all industries but allows for higher grants in biology and other specialized engineering sectors.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe R\u0026amp;D Fund\u0026rsquo;s preferential-path program provides product development grants to start-ups younger than five years. The recipients innovate in areas with high development risk, such as communications, cyber, hardware, medical equipment, and software.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA program specifically for cybersecurity provides grants of about 50  percent of a company\u0026rsquo;s R\u0026amp;D budget (up to about $600,000).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The strength of innovation in Israeli strategic industries"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Deep Blue"},"value":{"value":"deep-blue"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Scrolling"},"value":{"value":"scrolling"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Deep Blue"},"value":{"value":"deep-blue"}}},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"6"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe government initiative Startup Estonia has \u0026euro;7 million in funding to promote entrepreneurship and to enrich the start-up ecosystem by mobilizing start-ups, incubators, accelerators, other private-sector actors, and relevant public entities. It offers four categories of activities: community activation, training programs for young companies, investor support, and the facilitation of administrative processes. It also provides a database of start-ups and relevant service providers. As of 2022, the database included more than 1,300 start-ups and was catalyzing the whole Estonian start-up conversion funnel.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Startup Estonia"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Scrolling"},"value":{"value":"scrolling"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Gray"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"7"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe original research was conducted using various economic databases and public press searches. Company data are based on the Dealroom database, adjusted by local McKinsey experts. We assessed the state of Hungary\u0026rsquo;s start-up ecosystem in cooperation with Hungarian and international VC partners, angel investors, and start-up founders. \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/entrepreneurship-zeitgeist-2030\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s global research\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;supplemented the insights we received from them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eData collection\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article uses Dealroom\u0026rsquo;s database of all start-ups founded in Hungary, including those with headquarters outside the country. As a result of data inconsistencies in Dealroom, we reviewed the stages of start-ups and adjusted them if they were inconsistent with the expert view (for example, a start-up considered Series B in the database might have been adjusted, with expert input, to Series A in our model). We obtained the average net salary\u0026mdash;some  \u0026euro;1,450 per month (adjusted across maturity stages)\u0026mdash;based on expert input from Startup Hungary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eAssumptions\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eThe impact (both in funding and employment) of selected start-ups was excluded to take a conservative approach.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003ePre-seed: excluded as a result of incomplete data on Hungary (for instance, funding data were available for only 4 percent of pre-seed start-ups)\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eExit: excluded as a result of the limited availability of data on funding for Hungary\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eIPO: excluded because IPOs would disproportionately increase the funding and employment impact and because the main beneficiaries of a more active ecosystem are start-ups in earlier maturity stages (in other words, the additional impact for start-ups with a potential for IPOs was lower)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eImplemented measures will generate an impact from 2025 to 2030.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross maturity stages, only limited data on funding and employment were
